column1: HiWe are travelling to spain for the 2nd time in april. We would like to know how safe is it from the outbreak of coronavirus or is it just a media hype?

That would depend on where you are planning to go in Spain. I am planning travel to Barcelona in Mid-March and have been researching this question. There are currently two "hotspots" where "patient zero" (a person from whom others that have tested positive was the likely source of contagion). Vitoria in Basque country (northwest Spain) and Torrejón de Ardoz (a suburb of Madrid). Traveling to these areas might soon be a much higher risk. This clearly is NOT media hype! However, it is a bit early to make a decision on your trip in April. You should re-ask the question about three weeks before your planned arrival in Spain. LOTS can change in a month.

No one knows, just as no one knows whether and how far/how fast it will spread where you live. You need to watch for Government advisories and not base your decision on media hype. Remember, if a second person is diagnosed in a particular country, “two people have Coronavirus in X country” isn’t a headline; “numbers of people diagnosed has doubled in the last week” certainly is. Same story but the second sounds more dramatic.

There have been 151 cases of the virus in Spain. Only one man who was 69 years old died and he had been in Nepal. Most of the other cases were of people who had contracted the disease when they traveled to Northern Italy. Spanish health authorities are investigating all cases.A friend from the US sent me this article: A DOCTOR ADVISES DOCTORS RE THE CORONAVIRUS:"Date: February 26, 2020 at 2:35:50 PM ESTSubject: What I am doing for the upcoming COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemicDear Colleagues, as some of you may recall, when I was a professor of pathology at the University of California San Diego, I was one of the first molecular virologists in the world to work on coronaviruses (the 1970s). I was the first to demonstrate the number of genes the virus contained. Since then, I have kept up with the coronavirus field and its multiple clinical transfers into the human population (e.g., SARS, MERS), from different animal sources.The current projections for its expansion in the US are only probable, due to continued insufficient worldwide data, but it is most likely to be widespread in the US by mid to late March and April.Here is what I have done and the precautions that I take and will take. These are the same precautions I currently use during our influenza seasons, except for the mask and gloves.:1) NO HANDSHAKING! Use a fist bump, slight bow, elbow bump, etc.2) Use ONLY your knuckle to touch light switches. elevator buttons, etc.. Lift the gasoline dispenser with a paper towel or use a disposable glove.3) Open doors with your closed fist or hip - do not grasp the handle with your hand, unless there is no other way to open the door. Especially important on bathroom and post office/commercial doors.4) Use disinfectant wipes at the stores when they are available, including wiping the handle and child seat in grocery carts.5) Wash your hands with soap for 10-20 seconds and/or use a greater than 60% alcohol-based hand sanitizer whenever you return home from ANY activity that involves locations where other people have been.6) Keep a bottle of sanitizer available at each of your home's entrances. AND in your car for use after getting gas or touching other contaminated objects when you can't immediately wash your hands.7) If possible, cough or sneeze into a disposable tissue and discard. Use your elbow only if you have to. The clothing on your elbow will contain infectious virus that can be passed on for up to a week or more!James Robb, MD FCAP

As previously said, the situation is changing on a daily basis world over and just because a place has fewer confirmed cases today, does not mean that next week there won’t be a surge in confirmed cases. If you still wish to travel, then take the precautions suggested by healthcare professionals - keep washing hands, carry anti bac hand gel etc. If you must wear a face mask, wear it properly and not like some sort of fashion accessory! If however, you are one of the worried well and are getting anxious, then stay home and re-arrange your travel plans for another time.

"Just wait till virus spreads in your area and someone near you sniff and cough and accidentally spraying in your direction, what would you do then??If I am over 7 feet away, I don't need to do anything. And a common or garden mask that you see people wearing won't stop you catchingt the virus. Just because people are wearing the masks does not mean they are of any use - I am merely pointing out that the experts in the field clearly state that masks are only of use if you have the virus, and mitigate the chances of onward transmission.

I have taken 4 flights within the past 8 days and my comment about not wearing face masks like fashion accessories was based on what I saw. People are just not wearing them correctly. I have recently witnessed:1) People walking around the airport or cabin with the masks hanging around their necks, lifting them periodically to cover their mouths having touched various surfaces without washing hands or using sanitiser gel 2) Wearing masks on board aircraft only, when you are just as likely to be infected at the airport where there are even more people 3) Asian females taking selfies of themselves wearing masks combined with cat or bunny ear type headbands! 4) People in airport toilets wearing masks but not stopping to wash hands after using the toilet - failing in even the most basic hygiene 5) People wearing masks on their heads and then lowering to cover mouth at certain timesMy point is, if you are going to wear a mask then wear it properly, otherwise it offers absolutely no protection and can even put you at greater risk. Personally, I did not wear a mask but I did wash my hands frequently and thoroughly and used hand sanitiser during the flight.

How many cases there are in any particular country isn't the issue. The virus is now an issue everywhere, and is becoming steadily more serious. Decisions on whether or not to travel must be based on your personal risk factors, not on the opinions of strangers on a travel forum. The insouciance of people who offer reassurance of the "It's no worse than flu" and "Don't believe the scaremongering tabloids" kind is astonishing.For many people who contract the virus, it may be no worse than flu. For older people, and for anyone with existing health issues (i.e. respiratory problems, and diabetes) it is far more likely than flu to be a very serious illness, or fatal.If you are in this category, or even if you are young and healthy and don't mind the now considerable risk of getting ill, then don't worry and enjoy your travels. However, it surely makes sense, if you don't have to travel right now, to take the sensible precaution of keeping clear of crowds, such as in airports; and places where every surface you touch has been touched by dozens of people, such as aircraft (that's the easiest way to catch a cold at the best of times, even when no pandemic threatens). On the whole, the risk of contracting the virus is more in the time spent in such crowded places, than in the number of cases in the city or country you plan to visit.Edited: 4:20 am, March 08, 2020

As others have pointed out, every potential traveller has to measure the risks (as outlined by medical experts) and decide for themselves. We're booked for a trip in April as well, so are following Spain's stats closely. As of last week, verified cases have begun to increase by about 100 a day. This virus is highly contagious, and things will likely get worse than better. The bottom line is most people don't die from the virus. However, it can be a major inconvenience and expense to be quarantined for several weeks -- on vacation -- in another country. As well, I can't imagine hotels will welcome infected travellers with open arms. In some airports, travellers' temps are being taken if they have come from a heavily infected area, before they are allowed to enter the country. The situation is still unfolding of course, but these are some of the things we are keeping in mind before making a decision to travel to this part of Europe.
